message.content:
We need to “net‐out” only the changes recorded with type “Interest Receivables” (which normally–using the indirect method–enter as a change in an asset account) and then present the adjustment as an increase (a use of operating cash). In our data the only interest entries are those lines whose “type” is “Interest Receivables”. (There is no “interest received” recorded as paid, so the “unpaid” amounts all add up.) 

Step 1. Identify all rows with “Interest Receivables”. (For convenience we list the record “id” and the amount from the “amount” column.) In our new problem the entries are (all amounts are from the “amount” column):

 • Interest20240101001: 445.00  
 • Interest20240102002: 445.00  
 • Interest20240103003: 445.00  
 • Interest20240104004: 445.00  
 • Interest20240105005: 445.00  
 • Interest20240106006: 445.00  

 • Interest20240107007: 441.44  
 • Interest20240108008: 441.44  
 • Interest20240109009: 441.44  
 • Interest20240110010: 441.44  
 • Interest20240111011: 441.44  
 • Interest20240112012: 441.44  

 • Interest20240113013: 439.66    
 • Interest20240114014: 439.66  

 • Interest20240115015: 412.96  

 • Interest20240116016: 404.87  
 • Interest20240117017: 404.87  
 • Interest20240118018: 404.87  
 • Interest20240119019: 404.87  

 • Interest20240120020: 401.31  
 • Interest20240121021: 401.31  
 • Interest20240122022: 401.31  
 • Interest20240123023: 401.31  
 • Interest20240124024: 401.31  
 • Interest20240125025: 401.31  
 • Interest20240126026: 401.31  

 • Interest20240127027: 400.87  
 • Interest20240128028: 400.87  

 • Interest20240129029: 400.60  
 • Interest20240130030: 400.60  

 • Interest20240131031: 400.15  
 • Interest20240201032: 400.15  
 • Interest20240202033: 400.15  
 • Interest20240203034: 400.15  

 • Interest20240204035: 399.26  

 • Interest20240205036: 381.20  

Step 2. Sum up these amounts.

Let us group and add (amounts rounded to two‐decimals):

• Group 1 – first 6 rows: 6 × 445.00 = 2670.00  
• Group 2 – next 6 rows: 6 × 441.44 = 2648.64  
• Group 3 – next 2 rows: 2 × 439.66 = 879.32  
• Row 15: 412.96  
• Group 4 – four entries (rows 16–19): 4 × 404.87 = 1619.48  
• Group 5 – seven entries (rows 20–26): 7 × 401.31 = 2809.17  
• Group 6 – two entries (rows 27–28): 2 × 400.87 = 801.74  
• Group 7 – two entries (rows 29–30): 2 × 400.60 = 801.20  
• Group 8 – four entries (rows 31–34): 4 × 400.15 = 1600.62  
• Row 35: 399.26  
• Row 36: 381.20  

Now add sequentially:
 2670.00 + 2648.64 = 5318.64  
 5318.64 + 879.32 = 6197.96  
 6197.96 + 412.96 = 6610.92  
 6610.92 + 1619.48 = 8230.40  
 8230.40 + 2809.17 = 11039.57  
 11039.57 + 801.74 = 11841.31  
 11841.31 + 801.20 = 12642.51  
 12642.51 + 1600.62 = 14243.13  
 14243.13 + 399.26 = 14642.39  
 14642.39 + 381.20 = 15023.59  

Thus, the net total from all interest receivable transactions is 15,023.59.

Step 3. In a cash‐flow statement prepared by the indirect method an increase in an asset (here, “Interest Receivable”) is subtracted from net income. In our presentation the “(Increase) Decrease in Interest Receivable” item is shown as a negative (if the receivable increased). Since our combined “Interest Receivable” has risen by 15,023.59 we list this adjustment as “–15023.59”.

Thus, the final answer is:

{
  "solution": {
    "(Increase) Decrease in Interest Receivable": "-15023.59"
  }
}
